choices: Left!
Right!
111232.content:
"I have no intention to be shot." You state while slowly turning to the shark. He stops talking after a couple of seconds.

"Stay right there. You are under arrest-- or whatever Deluma said." The anthro responds. Does he know what he's talking about? He probably doesn't get why you need to be captured. Many anthros stop to look at this rather sudden scene.

"Do you even know what Deluma wants me for? Because I don't." You point out. He keeps his gun pointed at you.

"Uh... for running from the police-- yeah, that's it!" The young officer said. You shake your head.

"That's a good point, but that's not what I'm getting at." You retort. This guy doesn't even know what he is doing, does he. "Come on, you're not that stupid." You grunt.

"Hey!" The officer responds, taken aback by the comment. Now you don't know how to get to the other human. Different anthros have covered the entrance to the alleyway. Those bystanders may not be the officers, but they sure are tall enough to discourage you from accomplishing your goal.

"Come on! I don't want to go into a lab! What do you think they'll do to me in this 'SD Labs' of yours?!" You yell. You're very angry considering the amount of acrobatic skill you'd shown back near those other buildings that stand at your right. Many faces swing back and forth between you and the officer. The officer looks around nervously, debating something. "Please don't-- I don't belong here." You continue. That's right, wherever you are, you did not belong there. The officer keeps his hand steady. A couple of bystanders step forward and into the street. You look around. Maybe they can help me?

"Hey officer." Someone says. The officer looks over to see a strong looking bear anthro. He looks into the shark anthro's eyes.

"Back off, this is a police matter." The officer states. From the other side, a fox anthro speaks up.

"Are you even an officer?" The fox states. You see the officer breaking. If he is as new to the police as you believe, then he must be getting nervous thanks to the public.

"Yes-- back down." The officer states. You move backwards a bit. "Hey! Don't move or I'll shoot!" He yells. That escalated quickly... You stop.

"Don't shoot it!" An unidentifiable anthro shouts. Soon, multiple anthros are on your side. They start crowding the police officer as he protests and yells at them to back off and 'it's a police matter'. There is a ton of yelling. Two police vehicles clear around the corner behind the crowd. One is a large police van, and another is just a car. Police step out of the vehicle. You swear you could see Luna, but you don't take any chances and start bolting down the street, yelling 'Thanks!' and 'Thank you(s)' to anyone who could hear. Even though some anthros came to your defense, some still sided with the shark policeman. Many different anthros try to grab you as you elegantly duck and dive under and around them. This all leads into a fight that breaks out. Some police manage to escape the lock of the crowd and give chase.

You are small, but you run fast thanks to your gymnastic abilities. Quite literally you'd do flips to avoid some still-in-motion cars. There are many ways to get away... you must choose quick! While running down the street, you see to your left that there's an incline and beyond that is a large vehicle. Wait?! There's another human on there! But you can't exactly get to that human at the moment, but they're on the back of a truck-- presumably catching a ride. There's another large vehicle behind it, but with the different logos and such, you could tell it won't go in the same direction as that other human. You can climb on some conveniently jagged walls to leap onto it... but to your right there's another way to get out of your situation. To your right is another large street, crowded with more cars and unaware anthros who are going about their business. They must not know what was going on around the corner. Do you continue running to your right? Or do you try to get onto the bus behind the other human.

Left! (You will have to do some hardcore parkour, but you'll get away.)
OR
Right! (The street looks to give a cleaner getaway, but you'll have to keep running for a bit.)

Into the house!!
1112322.content:
Now, catching a ride would be the best idea, but that jagged wall is a bit of a risk to take when you have a clear option to your right.

You sway right, hair whipping around behind you. You're in a full-blown sprint now. Looking at these anthro-fied cars makes you want to do the cinematic thing where you run along on top of the cars, jumping onto each one as it's near. You scrap that idea as the cars are too big to jump onto. You run onto the sidewalk, bumping some anthros while running. About four seconds behind you are some cops. It seems that wolves are not as fast as you think. Pedestrians look at you then to the cops. There is a good gap between you and the officers in chase. You can hear their thunderous footsteps against the cement, but you can't look back to see them.

You're at another difficult choice-- left or forward. If you went right, you'd end up a street away from the riot; that'd probably get you caught. Forward of you is a rough-looking building. It looks broken down and abandoned, a perfect place to hide. You doubt the structural integrity of the building. You'd for sure find a place to hide, but it's two stories. The floor may be somewhat unstable. To your left-- a subway entrance. (NO not Subway™, I mean an actual subway TRAIN entrance. Man! Get yo thinkin' straight!) You could run down there... but what then? Wanna take your chances?

Run down into the subway! (*Sigh, continue the chase!) *Left
OR
Hide in the house! (You'll get away for sure... but can you trust that old house?) *Forward

You have no time to decide and run into the subway. Your hand slides along the large railing, it's smooth and it helps you go down the stairs. Anthros swing out of your way, not knowing what they were seeing. The police are following you closely, but not close enough as you get to the bottom of the steps. It looks as clean as an airport-- yet it was underground. There's a subway exit about fifty feet in front of you, leading back up into the surface. That's a pretty far stretch, but thanks to your acrobatic background, you are able to keep a good pace compared to the anthros chasing you. They will still catch up to you, but not before you reach the exit and continue running with yet another head start. You see a subway tunnel, y'know, one of the dark ones that trains go through.

You could run to the subway exit, inevitably continuing the chase.
OR
You could take your chances and run down the tunnel.

111232211.content:
You gain a burst of speed. You fly up the stairs with no sign of stopping. Some of the weird creatures moving on the stairs in and out of the subway had gotten wind of the commotion going down down below. A couple of them who have kids push them behind, making sure that the pale-looking thing running out of the subway doesn't harm.

You push by a kid who had this large hood on... and knock them down the stairs. You hear something you don't expect, a deep grunt, and looking back for half a second reveals that the kid had caught himself on the stairs, revealing a hand, a normal human hand!

"Shit!" the kid, now a man, mumbles to himself as on-goers switch back and forth between the escaping human and the one caught on the stairs. You don't have time to react as you get to the top of the stairs. Off in the distance are dark clouds. You could run in the direction of said clouds. Left of the subway exit was the street, with parked cars. The uproar you caused stopped cars for complete city blocks. If the clouds didn’t lie, they are heading your direction, a perfect getaway! Those cops wouldn’t be able to smelly ou for a mile!

Before you start running, some groups of people looked on and back into the subway, as on the stairs, the cops apprehended the other human. You hear the man shouting at the officer things. You feel kind of bad for putting him in that situation. Should you help him> Maybe the both of you could team up on them, or run.

Run to the clouds?

Help the man.
111232211.title: Get outta there!

choices: Look for the other humans?
Find a way to disguise yourself?
1112322111.content:
While looking back down, you make eye contact with the apprehended person. You frown and feel pity-

"Go!" He shouts. You are shocked, he forgave you?! Without pause you turn around and sprint down the sidewalk.

The tall animals are going crazy, pushing and shoving each other at this point for no reason whatsoever. It seems that the only people that have a cause to make commotion are the ones a couple blocks over, the ones that are surrounding the cops. You sidestep and jump over miscellaneous objects and what appears to be broken glass. You hear roars and screeches. You see some animals have gotten out of the craziness by sliding into the alleyways. Loud honks and the sound of breaking glass seems to deafen everything else. You duck under random claws and shift your weight to get ready to continue running. Thunder goes off in the distance.

"Come here you!" A loud and hoarse yell grabs your attention. By this point you were crossing a street. You look to see the multiple-tailed mayor. Deluma. Your eyes widen and you start running faster.

"Nope!" You yelp as you jump over her swiping tails. Deluma roars and jumps to tackle you. You squeeze just{/} under her arms and continue sprinting down the street once more.

"Get back here!!" She screams as she recovers. You're out of sight by the time she gets up however. You're sprinting so fast that you can feel the wind between every square inch of your hair.

There are shouts of anger and shouts of, what sounds like, rebellion. Maybe this town was in deep doo-doo before you got here anyway. If they hate the mayor then you completely agree.

------

It takes about an hour to finally reach the outskirts of town. There are helicopters roaming the whole city. The outskirts are normal and don't have angry mobs. The authorities have completely forgot about the three humans that were running through the city. Three humans. You, the one with glasses, and the one with the overly-large jacket. You were able to find a small street that hid you from the animals, and you followed it. It is lightly sprinkling.

It hits you that you've been sprinting for almost an hour, and you don't feel so well. You scan the area to find a lonely house. It's for sale. Your vision gets a bit blurry and the distant feeling of a headache roams around. You breath heavily and slow down to a light jog as you near the house. You go around the side and over to a backdoor. It's a nice-looking house with a backdoor. You walk up to the backdoor and your training kicks in. You pull out the very loose hairpin that, surprisingly, stuck to your hair. You bend it and shove it into the lock. You stop picking the lock to lean against the door for a moment; You need to lay down. You lazily fidget with the lock and it opens. You stumble in and close the door, remembering to take your hairpin out of the lock. You carefully investigate the empty house, and with checking the last room, you fall over and catch yourself on a doorknob. You close the door. You use your training once again to tear a strip of rugged carpet off the floor, and test its strength, then you use it to tie up the door and the window. There's no way anyone is gonna get in here. You walk over to a wall and slowly drag yourself down.

"Finally." You sigh. You put a hand on your head and massage your scalp, you've got a headache. It's raining now too. The sky is gray and slightly darker than normal. Shuffling in place, you notice that you might have pulled a couple of muscles trying to get out of harm's way. After a couple of minutes your eyes have shut.

------

You wake up in your bed, yawning. The events that had occurred in your dream were simply ridiculous, and it felt like forever. You smile knowing that you used your training effectively. You silently thank your dad for helping. You stretch to see your soft pink pajamas on. You sit up in your bed and scoot over to look at the clock. It's a normal seven a.m.

"Nice." You say, your voice sounds a little more optimistic than usual. You don't seem to focus on your room's details that much as you look over towards the window.
There's a calming, simple light flooding the room. You feel ecstatic as you stand up. You notice something that you didn't feel before- you're wearing the same clothes as in your dream. You quickly check your hair and it's all messy, you gasp and look around the room, the same colors on the wall were there just as they had been before you went to sleep--! You glance back over to the window and you see that it's smaller, and tied up. There is a knock on the door and you spin to see it open.
You see the angry face of Deluma, her uniform is dirty and her fur looks matted. Her tails enter from the door from different angles. You shriek and push your back against the wall, the bed was no longer there. Her figure seems to grow darker and her eyes start to glow red, her tails grow in size and cast long shadows across the room. You close your eyes and curl up in a ball as if you were five years old.


You gasp and jut forward, clutching your heart, that was a nightmare alright! You quickly calm down. It's light out and it's no longer raining. You slept for a long time. You roll over and push yourself off the ground. You feel sore, but the headache is gone!

You hear the jingling of keys and the sound of a door opening, you realize you've outstayed your welcome. You quickly head over to the window and loosen the knots and ties with a single pull. You rush over to the door and repeat. You crumble the two equally long straps of carpet into your pockets and crouch. You slowly open the door and peer out. You don't see anything but the empty house. You do hear talking though. If it's for sale, these people would have to be salesmen. You look over to the door that you entered last night and slowly start creeping to it. You close the door behind you.

"My shoes are soaked, honey." A female voice whines. You get closer to the exit door.

"Well don't worry, are your socks dry?" A male voice replies with care. You notice a desk that was by the door, there are a couple of water bottles there, and a plate of cookies. Guess you didn't see it in your tired stupor. You've seen those things before when your family moved. You grab two water bottles.

"And here are the stairs, custom built, there is an option for a private suite in this section of the house, it's this way." A quirkier female explains. You slide through the backdoor and close it. You carefully walk around the house and into the backstreet.

You're a bit hungry, but you can handle it thanks to your training. It's a big city, and you don't know where you are or what you're doing. There were two other humans, maybe they were caught. Maybe they weren't... you for sure don't know what happened to the one with glasses, but you think that the one with the overly large jacket got away. He looked and sounded tough, and he didn't call for help when you accidentally forced him into a tight situation...

What now?
1112322111.title: Leave him.

Call for help! (Good karma to you)
1112322112.content:
You don’t like fighting in places you are not familiar with, but you can’t just leave another person at the hands… paws, of larger and possibly dangerous creatures!

You rush back down the stairs and see that the other person is- fighting?! This man you bumped is no pushover! Will full force you tackle into one of the officers, effectively toppling everyone over, except yourself, of course. Superior agility helps in tough situations. You spin around to see if any other officers were rushing into the scene, however, there are some bystanders who look like they’re about to charge in and help their officers. You skip over to the downed human and you help him up. He takes a blind swing and almost catches your hair.

“Hey! Come on, we gotta go!” You yell at him. He looks up to see your face, and he blushes.

“Sorry-”

“Shut up! Come on!” You exclaim. Letting him go, you start running out the way to the clouds. With the man following behind you, you reach the bottom of the stairs. At the top you see flashing lights, more cops! You turn around and it seems that the human you helped was already on finding another exit. The officers have gotten up at this point. You rush over to the man and he runs into the tunnel.

You hop and prepare to land, but suddenly you’re grappled by two large arms. You squeak- whatever has you is pulling you up. You kick out at the air and punch the arms, but they refuse to let go.

“I got one!” The voice says, it’s one of the cops. “Help me, John!” The officer calls out. You hear the loud footsteps of another officer animal.

What do you do?
1112322112.title: Help the man.

choices: Continue getting out of your handcuffs?
Try to steal the vehicle.
11123221121.content:
You’re not just gonna let them take you! You swing your head back in hopes of hitting the officer in the head, but you forcefully hit the bottom of the subway sidewalk. Your vision gets a bit blurry for a moment and you goran. Your back is dragged up the side and it rips a bit, but this means now that you’re able to fight back. You use your training to punch the thing in their face, and it hurts. The animal releases you and you bolt. Yet once again, you’re caught by another pair of arms.

“Let go of me!” You yell, but the “John” forces you to the ground like a real officer. You struggle to get out of this oppressive grip. The other officer rushes over to help his fellow. Off in the distance, you see the human you helps is looking back at you, and starts running to help.

The sound of a large, and fast train startles you and the human. BYstanders watch in horror as the train comes speeding through the tunnel. The human runs as fast as he can to avoid the train, but he runs right out of your sights. Some of the bystanders scream and gasp. You’re handcuffed now, and the officers have switched their attention to the crowd, and the to the train. They look at each other and realize they forgot about the human in the jacket who was down on the train tracks.

“No!” You scream. The human you helped just got hit by the train!. You trash around violently in the officer’s grip. The “John” pushes you harder onto the floor of the subway.

“We got one, at least. Help me with this one.” ‘John’ says to the other officer. The other one nods,

------

You sit inside of a large, black van that has police decals on it. The images of the train keep intruding into your thoughts. You use your training once again to figure a way out of the cuffs. The door to the vehicle slams shut.

Other officers are on the scene and an emergency vehicle has arrived… along with the sleek limo that you recognize.

On the outside, there’s tape that surrounds the entrance to the subway. Some of the medics come up and speak to the officers, then to the multiple-tailed jerk who called you her property. She lashes her tails out and you hear yelling. Seems like she just received the bad news.

Then her attention suddenly turns to the police vehicle you’re in. You stop fiddling with the handcuffs. All the anger you felt beforehand increases exponentially. You’re so angry you slam on the side of the van hoping to instigate something with that prissy animal. She walks over to the van. You make eye contact with her. She stares at you.

“You’re gonna be a pain.” She says, and it sounds muffled due to there being a barrier between you two.

She walks away and you’re left there in an angry state. You turn in your seat to see a sliding door. Presumably to speak back and forth. It’s huge! You guess you could even fit through it!
11123221121.title: Fight your way out.

choices: Go with your plan. (They may sniff you out... literally)
Listen to Kiba. (This dude is a strategist... you should probably listen to him)
11123221122.content:
“Hey! Hey- help!” You yell at the person you helped. He turns around and sees your situation. He runs back and grabs your legs. Even though the creature is huge, he can’t handle two people. You’re pulled out of the animal’s arms and immediately start running. The officer tries to chase you.

“It can speak!” One officer exclaims to another.

“They were talking about it on the radio-”

A large sound echoes through the tunnels, it’s a train! You run to the side of the track, and jump up. You look back down to see that the man you rescued needs help again. You forget that you’re more agile. You reach a hand down and pull him up just in time for the train to pass, hiding the both of you. Further ahead, the officer had scrambled up, relief spreading across his face as he is out of harm’s way.



You exchange glances with the man. “My name is Kiba.” he huffs. The both of you are out of breath, and it took you until now to realize this. “You?”

“Terra.” You reply, “We should start going, the train won’t be here long.” You finish.

“Thank you, Terra.” Kiba says. You nod. The two of you get up and start jogging down the tunnel.

------

About an hour later, you’re both in near-complete darkness, and you’re both sitting down, a couple feet inbetween.

“So, do you know where we are?” You ask Kiba. He looks at you with a slightly annoyed expression.

“You think I know? I have no idea.” He replies.

“Oh, well, I thought you knew, your jacket makes you look like you’re cool or something.” You say. He chuckles then takes a moment to look at his clothes.

“Well, where do you think we are?” Kiba repeats your question.

“I don’t know.” You answer. You shuffle in place and feel a slight bump in your pant leg. Suddenly you realize that you were getting ready to visit an out of state campground, because you had friends who worked there. It was a small, handheld LED flashlight. You reach into your right pocket with some effort and pull it out.

“What’s that?” Kiba asks. You smile.

“It’s a flashlight.” You say giddily.

“Why would you have a flashlight in your pocket?” He questions.

“Well, I don’t like being where I can’t see, or places I don’t know… and I was going to a campground back at…” You stop talking when you click on the small flashlight. It doesn’t turn on. “What?!” You exclaim. You smack the back of the flashlight a couple times. “I just bought this damn thing!”

“Were batteries included?” Kiba asks innocently. You glare at him and he looks the other way shyly.

“No.” Your expression softens. Sighing, you put it back into your pocket. Nevermind that then. You doubt that the creatures around have the right batteries… or batteries at all.

“Well, what should we do?” Kiba asks as he prepares to get up. You admit you have no idea. “Well, we could try walking.”

“Alright.” You agree.

------

It feels like forever until you hit a section of the tunnel where there’s a split. Although, one of the ways is blocked by large, jagged rocks. The train tunnel you’re in is shaped like any normal one you’d find. However, it is large, so large it seems to fog when it gets cold… which it is now cold now.

“What do you think happened here?” Kiba asks. You shake your head.

“I don’t know. Maybe it collapsed? Looks like that’s what happened.” You answer.

“Maybe they just haven’t gotten around to fixing it then.” Kiba says. “Well I guess we’re going left now.”

“Oh hey, it’s brighter down there!” You exclaim.

“Why be happy about that? With what we know, that could just mean trouble.” Kiba quickly retorts. You sigh and agree.

“Well, it’s probably late.” You say. Kiba pulls out his phone. “Wha--! Yo--? You had that the whole time?!” You whisper sharply.

“It We just escaped death, Terra.!” Kiba replies sharply. You roll your eyes. “It’s about 12:00.” He announces.

“Well… it felt like they were actually trying to capture us. Since we didn’t harm anyone, unless you did,” You look at him. He frowns and shakes his head no, “Good, then they had no reason to shoot us.”

“We’re innocent.” Kiba says. It occurred to you that you were talking as if the creatures were human.

“They are intelligent. I think. They had cars and stuff.” You say. The both of you continue walking, the lights seem so far away.

“Yeah, it feels like I never left the city. Do you think they’re just as advanced as we are?”

“Are we in the future?”

“Maybe, but how though?”

“No we can’t be in the future, everything is too relevant…”

“What if the creatures are humans, and to them, we look like the creatures?”

“If we were the creatures, why would they try to tackles us down?”

“Well, we are smaller than them… cops are also supposed to be brave.”

“Not all of them are, I know a couple that were distant relatives of mine.”

This conversation continues until the two of you stop talking. You’re close to the train exit. It dawns on you suddenly that there could be nocturnal type creatures walking around.

“Walking.” You think to yourself. You tap KIba on the shoulder and you both stop.

“If it’s late, do you think there will be nocturnal creatures?” You whisper. Kiba smacks his forehead.

“Gah, you’re right. What should we do?” Kiba whispers back.

“Well, wait, you stay here for a moment, I will go check.” You say. The two of you are close to the train exit. You can see the colors of Kiba’s jacket again.

“No, no that’s too risky, I’ll go.” Kiba says.

“What? No why?” You retort.

“Well…. er, I uh, I should do it anyway.” Kiba answers you shyly. You swear that you see a blush but you can’t tell in this lighting.

“Look I have training, Kiba.” You whisper sharply.

“Well- I’m a boxer so-” Kiba starts speaking. Out of the corner of your eye, you see the train exit, and a couple tails. You see that there are creatures lined up as if to get on a train. You don’t hear anything other than Kiba’s voice and distant talking.

You cut Kiba off. “Hey, look.” Kiba stops talking and looks in the direction you’re pointing. “They look like they’re about to get on a train. Come on, let’s get up on the side.”

Kiba nods. “Alright, yeah.” He says.

------

The two of you get up on the side, of course, you had to pull him up again, because he couldn’t jump up there without help. A large sound goes off in the distance. It’s the train. After a moment, it stops. The creatures that were lined up get onto the train. It then picks up its speed and flies by the two of you.

After a minute, the distant talking fades. There can’t be any more than a couple creatures left in the subway.

You have an idea for what you can do. You alone will sneak around and try to find batteries and have Kiba wait for you. Your training will 100% keep you out of sight, and they won't hear you.

“Terra, I have an idea.” Kiba states with confidence.
11123221122.title: Call for help!

choices: Sneak around the block with Kiba to find some information.
Sneak around by yourself.
111232211222.content:
"What is it?" You ask, though deep in your gut you felt that your plan was going to work...

It takes him a moment before he relies, obviously the man was thinking, "We were talking earlier, you remember?"

"Of course I remember." You whispers sharply, indignantly.

"Well then you would know how to sneak around..." Kiba trails off in thought, a brief chill crawls up your spine as you two are crouched and near the large aliens, just around them, just out of sight, "maybe..."

"Spit it out- we don't have much time until the next train comes!" You spit under your breath, although you didn't really know the truthfulness to that statement.

Kiba grunts, "They're animals- you must have realized at this point. Animals can smell you. Even if you got around unseen, your scent, my scent, could easily be tracked. They must know we're here, not because of smell, but because we had caused a scene at the other station. Wouldn't it make sense that, in not their police, their cameras to work?" You stare at him with a mix of interest and disgruntlement.

"Sure. Their cameras work, but not all of them are dogs-"

"They're animals! Not just dogs, animals! We have to make a distraction, which I wouldn't be opposed to doing." Kiba buts in harshly, finding difficulty in not raising his voice above a whisper.

"Just for batteries?"

"Batteries? Batteries are your concern right now? I thought we were trying to find a way out of this place! We can get batteries when we're above the surface, Terra... Terra's your name right?" He argues doggedly, you didn't know whether to feel stupid or thankful, but he was right. To the surface was the better option.

"Yes... come on, what are we doing then, Kiba."

"Well..."

------

Kiba still had his overly large jacket, which would pass him off as a kid. It had worked previously until your sudden intervention. Frankly, without there being much notice to his apparel to the police, he could still pull it off without bystander attention. What Kiba was going to really do, you couldn't know. He left out a few details of his plan, you were apprehensive about the whole ordeal, the fear of him being caught or abandoning you was strong, but his logic was flawless.

You were to head back into the cave and wait for him to return with another jacket, or cover, or something, to pass you off as a younger creature as well.

------

It was dark. Cold. You huddled against the cold stone, where the collapsed tunnel entrance was. It was your decision to wait here. Kiba had suggested you stay close, but he agreed that maybe it was safer, until he returned, that you stayed where both of you could meet. Though it was still distant to you, this small grouping of rocks felt better to stay with than those massive aliens, and also you could just crawl into a small space to conceal yourself from sight if need be.

Only the silence of darkness and creeping of low temperatures were your friends. You wish that you were at camp, with your friends, with the familiar, warm smiles that you were expecting to face rather than wherever you are right now.

Light crunches of gravel grab your attention. You peek over the rocks and look around, your eyes having been adjusted to the darkness already, though still it was hard to see. A tingling fear gripped at your chest, you wanted to call out for Kiba, to make sure that you were safe, but you had to be vigilant and silent, he was to come to you.

"Still here?" Kiba whispers loudly.

"Yes." You reply, he flinches, not expecting a response from his far right.

"I have the jacket," he says, holding out a blind hand, and a ridiculously oversized piece of clothing, "come on, let's get out of here."

------

After putting on the jacket, which made you look like a dude, which didn't matter much, the two of you carefully made your way back and up into the subway entrance. The two of you made a smooth exit and had found your way to the surface. Now all you needed to do was either figure out where you were or figure out where you could get batteries, obviously the former first, but above else you and Kiba were in need of a place to hide.

You and Kiba stood together in a lone alleyway, both of you hidden in the shadows of the huge buildings, debating whether to split or walk together. No matter which, you both were to meet back here.
111232211222.title: Adept To Planning

choices: Look for an exit...? (Might find cops.)
Stay down there for a bit. (Might find a friendly anthro.)
111232212.content:
You skid around to your right, immediately heading to the tunnel. Looking behind you and in front of you, there are no trains coming at the moment. Your footsteps gain a large echo after about five seconds within the tunnel, and your breathing also echoes. You don't know where you're going, but you know you're going down a tunnel.

Behind you, the cops are pushing past people to get to you. People are making shocked remarks and angry snaps at them, then they realize they're cops. Back ahead of you, the tunnel seems to stretch on and on. You're a good distance in the tunnel, running on the very thin slip of sidewalk there is. Your height gives you an advantage as you hear one of the cops trip and fall onto the tracks. You know this because you looked behind. You keep running since the cops are still in chase, and you start to get tired.

"I can't stop... yet." You mumble whilst running. You speed it up a bit to gain some distance, but suddenly it just goes completely dark. You stutter along the walker, trying to stay in your balance. You hear feedback and a click.

"Human heading towards the eastern entrance, send backup, it's fast." The officer exclaims quickly into his mic. Your eyes are barely adjusted, but your ears work. The officer had sent a quick, simple relay that stroke a bit of hesitance and fear into your safety.

---------------

You only hear your subtle, small footsteps now. You feel as the cold air surrounds your body and chills your arms and legs and face. You stop moving. You look back and forth and then unto the tracks themselves. Multiple pillars spread out to keep the heavy cement and stone that the city is on top of. You press your back against the wall and slowly drop down. Your legs touch the cold stone below and you jerk your leg up.

"Cold..." You whisper aloud. You fix your hair, and fix your messy clothes a bit. Girls like to keep up a certain standard, unlike guys, so you take about five minutes to fix your hair and tidy up. When you're done, you simply hold up the thin, plastic thing you barely call a comb. You think about what just happened. Whew... I just, I think I--, I don't know where I am, do I? Ran away from some weird, tall creatures dressed in cop outfits and had fur on them. Some had talons too, and claws... and teeth...

You lean your head back and close your eyes, curling up to keep warm in this very cold, foggy, dry tunnel. It was big enough to encompass a small fog. Must be raining above, but with the thick cement, you can't really tell.

----------------

About an hour goes by, the cops must have been waiting for you to come out of one of the entrances, but then again, there could be more than what's ahead and behind, because tunnels usually split. You slowly open your eyes, not having slept, but have rested. You get up, and you realize that curling up on cement has made your tailbone a bit sore. Along with literally every other joint in your body. You continue forward, hoping to find a different way out. These train tracks seem to go on forever, but then again, the height of these inhabitants also seem to go on and on forever.

You walk for another twenty minutes when you hear the very, very subtle sound of footsteps. Heavy, dull, yet very quick footsteps. You can't tell where it's coming from, but you start running. The other footsteps suddenly get really loud, and they're fast. You gasp as you suddenly trip over a crack. You stumble a bit, but manage to grab onto a pipe, breaking your fall. You push yourself off of the pipe and run again.

-----------------

You lose the cops once again. But this time, you're hungry, and thirsty. Tired, and cold. You need to do something. The darkness persists, and it's hard to adjust. You slowly walk, the crack you tripped on hurt your leg, and thanks to adrenaline, you didn't feel it until now. You limp down the tunnel, even with your past experience to be able to deal with these situations, there is simply nothing you can do, nothing you can use, just- nothing. A tear forms down your eye. You close them for a moment to rub them... and you freak out when your foot hits doesn't hit the floor, but hits air. You swing your hand to try to find something to grab, but it ends up in you turning around for nothing, and you fall backwards. You wince as your back hits a hard slope, and you tumble down into a small opening. You brace your head and curl up-- at least, you try to.

You scream as you tumble. You can't even see anything. 'Help!',you cry in your head. You roll down the dirty slope, hitting miscellaneous things on the way. Plants and small rocks start to fall too, and roll with you. You finally stop at the bottom of the slope. Dust flutters around you as you groan in anger. You slam your fist against the ground. "Son of a..." You mumble under your breath. You roll over and sit up. You put your hand against your head. You feel your legs and arms to make sure nothing is injured. Your back feels sore, but nothing was injured.

It occurred to you that a small crack in the subway did more damage to your leg than what a tumble down a slope could do to anything. You chuckle a bit. You grunt as you stand up. It's so dark, you can't see anything even if your eyes adjusted. You look around. The silence rings in your ears.

You suddenly hear a ripple of water. You blindly look towards the water's general direction. You take a stance and slowly place one foot in front of the other, so you don't trip down another slope. You continue until your foot hits the ice-cold water in this dark place. From a subway, to a tunnel, to this... cave? Who cares. Cupping your hands, you grab water.

-------------------
111232212.title: Into the dark...

choices: You wake up in a very soft place... a bed maybe?
(Reader's Choice)
11123222.content:
You rush through your options and you decide to hide in the house. While running, you see that the house has a tall, rickety fence and a large caution sign on it. There is a small fence gate with a lock attached to a metal chain that secures the door. You can't climb that! You take a quick glance behind you, there are three large wolf-looking anthros chasing you. Wait, no, that one's a dog. You look forward again, you're about 20 feet away from the house. There's a large rhino-looking anthro walking by the house, conveniently next to the smallest part of the fence. You realize you might have to use that anthro to hop the fence. You hesitate, but you're 5 feet from the rhino. He looks at you, eyes widening. You jump behind him, grabbing onto his shirt and pulling up. It boosts you juuust enough to hop over the fence. Sadly the rhino falls backwards thanks to you.

"Sorry!" You grunt, it took a lot of effort. The three officers end up crashing into the fence, they are not tall enough to get in either. They break through, falling on one another. Two of them yelp while one hits his his head on a mailbox, knocking em' out. You are now on the porch of this very, very old looking house. You glance back before going into the house, one officer is tending to the one still on the ground while the other is halfway across the yard. You enter the house. It's unlocked so you're able to get in. Closing the door, you jump to reach the lock and lock it. That gave you some time.

You don't look downstairs and immediately run up the stairs. You open a couple windows at the top to make it look like you jumped out. The floors creak really loud, but there's nothing you can do about it right now, you have to find a place to hide! You hear banging on the door, must be the officer. There are four doors into different rooms. You're not a strategist... or a fighter. Maybe you can fit in a smaller place?

CRASH!!


You jump at the sound, but you cover your mouth in time to muffle your scream. You catch a glimpse of the room to your left-- a closet! Rushing in, you close the door behind you and jump into the closet, closing that as well. About four hours go by before you don't hear anyone in the house.

Opening the closet door, you see that the anthros have searched the room you were in. It's good that they didn't check in the closet. You sigh, relieved that you got away. Feeling your body, you notice that you feel sore after being in a standing position for a while. You stretch.

"Yes!" You whisper, pumping your right fist in triumph. You skip over to the window in the room, no cops, but there's still a very identifiable break in the fence. You chuckle. You sit on the bed in the room for a while, about ten minutes so you can leave. You think that staying here would not be the best idea so you get up. Passing through the doorway you hear how loud the house sounded when you took a step. I see why the last tenants didn't want the house anymore. Suddenly, your foot gets caught in a broken plank. "What the f- oh. Just a board." You gasp. Your heart skipped a beat for a moment. You yank your foot out of the broken floorboard. You hear a loud creek-- and then it goes silent. Hesitantly, you take another step. The floor completely breaks from under you! You scream and fall backwards, landing on the bottom floor. You lay on a large pile of wood that was once the floor above you.

"Aughh-- that... sucked." You groan. Large clouds of dust flutter around the bottom floor. You open your eyes to see one last piece of wood falling, straight on your head. It knocks you out.

114.content:
"Your scent is off," the wolf said.
"Me?" you say, "What do you mean?"
"You really have no clue about wolves, do you?"

You stumble around your next words. Maybe you should just stay silent. It would be better, but this wolf is eying you. Her eyes are suspicious. As you stand, you realize she's threatening you. You may not know much about wolves and their body language, but it is clear with the violent expression in her eyes.

"I don't do that kind of stuff." you say.
"What stuff?" the wolf said, "I'd be careful with your next words."
"I am not a naturalist and I never planned to be one," you say.
"Don't insult me," the wolf said, "and don't make it worse for yourself. Speak up."

She howls. You shudder. The howls were supposed to be beautiful, according to the Naturalists. They just served as a wild taunt, or maybe they were to call other officers. As your eyes survey everything around you, you see multiple other wolves all standing around you.

"You do not appear to be a citizen," she said, "we would've smelled it on you."
"You're eerie," you say.
"Eerie?" she said.
"You smell me?" you said, "You know who I am by my scent?"

A polite smile lines her face. Maybe it's just a taunt. This is before she turns to her officers. They all swarm around her, ready for her next orders. A slight nod signals action. Many guns all point towards your head. You're just not used to so many animals who have the best aim.

"On the ground," she says.
"What?" you say.
"You're under arrest," she says.
"For a few comments?" you say.
"Don't make this worse for yourself," she says, "my dogs would be glad to play with their toys if they get the chance."

You glance at the guns. There's no way out. After a long hard swallow, you realize how the wolf is serious. Her gaze only helps to make you feel worse. You comply with her orders, though worried about what might happen. You are on the ground, with your hands lifted.

The satisfied smile on the wolf's face only serves to make you feel worse.

115.content:
You don't know where you are or how you got there. But you know you don't belong there. You push your way through the crowd, all the anthros in the crowd are clamoring around you as they try to get a better look or snap pictures of you on their phones. You weren't interested in staying to find out if they were peaceful. The first thing you needed to do was find some secluded area where you could get a handle on what was going on.

         You didn't make it very far however before police cars came screeching down the street and stopped ahead of you. You paused and backtracked in the opposite direction, but only to find police cars pulling up there as well. Several officers got out to do crowd control while two in particular approached you.

         "What have we here?" One asked. He was a male German Shepherd in a standard police uniform.

         "It looks like this... creature... is the cause of the disruption," The other officer; who turned out to be a male tiger noted.

         "Any idea as to what it is?" The Shepherd asked.

         "I couldn't say," The tiger replied, "But we can't leave it here."

         "Let's get a containment unit down here and get it locked down and back to the station. We can figure more out there," The Shepherd suggested.

         You didn't like that at all. You took a couple of steps back and scowled at the Shepherd. This didn't go unnoticed by the tiger. "Did you see that?" He asked.

         "See what?" The Shepherd replied.

         "His entire demeanor changed when you mentioned the containment unit and taking him back to the station," The tiger stated as he gazed at you with wonder.

         The Shepherd looked down at you and then back to the tiger, "Did it?" He asked.

         You were really tired of the conversation and began looking for a way to escape. The answer came to you in the form of an open manhole cover.

         "Based on his reactions so far, its entirely possible that he is able to understand us. Or at the very least he can sense the meaning behind our tones," The tiger mused.

         "You do realize how far fetched that sounds, right?" The canine asked.

121.content:
"Its raining," Tom muttered. Rain was good, rain meant he'd be harder to track. Rain also meant that he would sleep well when night fell and hear the splashing footsteps of his pursuers. It had been three years since he'd arrived here. He was a sixteen year old high school student who's biggest problem was the beating the rival school's sprinter. Now, he was a nineteen year old survivor. He spent his days moving from alley to alley avoiding police and other 'stray humans' as anthros called them. When he initially arrived he was scared and confused, he sought help. He found it in the form of a German Shepherd police officer. The officer dropped him off at a shelter for humans where they were taken care of until they were adopted by an anthro family. The shelters weren't that bad, and for the most part, humans were well taken care of. It was like staying in a hotel. Of course humans weren't allowed to leave and there was a curfew that basically locked humans in their rooms at night.

         However, the status of humans AFTER they were adopted that was the problem. They were either adopted and treated very well or adopted and treated horribly. Either way, the best that a human could hope for was to be adopted as a pet, and there was only a fifty-fifty chance of that happening. The idea of someone's pet or slave didn't appeal to Tom. So the first opportunity he got, he left the shelter and never looked back. He'd been living on the streets ever since. He adapted quickly, learning to stay ahead of police and detectives and to avoid fellow humans who had turned to raiding people like him. Trust no one, speak only when necessary and keep moving... those were the rules he made for himself and those were the rules he followed.

         The police treated stray humans like escaped convicts. Capturing them was a priority, but if a citizen caught a stray, they were within their rights to keep it. Tom had his fair share of close calls with both, and tongight would be no different, or at least... he hoped it wouldn't. Unfortunately for him he held the record for the longest free roaming stray. Most strays only went for a few months before they're caught, but Tom had been a stray now for over two years. Various police officers and detectives had turned finding a catching him into a competition, and he was the prize...

1213.content:
Tom Wrapped himself in his cloak before putting his baseball cap on. They were the only two things that he had left of his old life. The cap had the 1990's Disney channel emblem stitched on the front of it, while the cloak resembled a lightweight rain poncho, though it was made of fabric instead of plastic. It was a gift from his father who'd bought it for him after he one day complained about being cold at the start of a track meet at school. He didn't want to wear sweats as he'd eventually shed them after he started to warm up, so his father bought him a cloak. He then shouldered his shoulder bag and walked over to a nearby window where he slipped out and quietly scaled the drain pipes to get to the roof of the abandoned building he was staying in. He quietly walked along until he came to an old air conditioning unit that sat at the edge of the building and watched as the rain fell onto the city from a cloudy grey sky.

         It brought him peace, he found something soothing about the gray sky and the constant tapping of the rain against the stone rooftop of the building and the concrete streets. Even before he was brought to this place, he loved to run in the rain, there was just something about having his hair matted down and water running down his face as he splashed though puddles along old dirt running trails and sidewalks. As he reminisced and remembered, his mental oasis was shattered by the sound of a tactical boot stepping in a nearby puddle. Tom's eyes snapped open as he leapt off of his perch and dropped off of the side of the roof.

         The German Shepherd that had been closing on him ran to the edge of the roof and looked down expecting to find a lifeless body lying limp on the street below. But he instead found tom dashing down a fire escape. "All units, target is headed down to the street on the North side of the building!" He called through his radio as he climbed over the ledge to give chase.

         Tom's shoes touched down on the sidewalk walk with a wet 'splat' after leaping over the last flight of stairs. He looked to his left to find a very familiar Doberman running towards him with a very smug grin on his face, "Terran..." Tom muttered to himself, his face full of distaste as he spat the name before running in the opposite direction. It wasn't long before the street behind him was filled with officers trying to run him down.

         The Doberman continued to give chase with his squad of officers, "This time! This time, we have him!" He told himself.

         A squad car pulled itself directly into Tom's path blocking the street from him. Tom however, sprinted even harder before throwing himself across the hood of the car and resuming his sprint.

Tom walked into his room and locked the door behind himself with a deadbolt lock. He glanced over the room, a television, bed, fan and lamp were all it had as far as amenities. There was a balcony, but it overlooked the street below and that was about it. "Better get to work," Tom muttered as he climbed on top of the bed. He unscrewed the bolts holding the vent grate in the ceiling, he then opened his bag and rummaged around in it until he found a pocket knife. He put an ear to one of the walls of his room and after determining that nobody else was on said room, he began carving a hole in the wall with some effort. He stepped back to admire his work when he finished. He could clearly see into the next room, and with a bit of effort, even cross into it. After that was done Tom went out onto the balcony, he found that while he had access to the street, being so high would make it a difficult escape tonight as he was three stories up. Thankfully though, Tom had a rope in his bag for just such an emergency. He took the rope out and went to the neighboring room where he laid it on the balcony, he then tied one end to the railing and left the rest where it lay. With his prep work done, the human flopped down on the bed and closed his eyes keeping his bag close by.

         Two hours after Tom had dozed off, a leopard followed by two mice entered the lobby of the motel. All were dressed in navy blue tactical suits and all were armed with an array of both lethal and nonlethal weapons adorning their belts. An assortment of tools also joined the weapons around their waist lines. The raccoon, who'd been reading his paper, set his news article aside as the group approached his desk. "Where is he?" The leopard asked in a cool and collected tone. His green eyes seemed to glow under the 'police' baseball cap he wore.

         "Room 302 on the third floor. He looked tired so he's probably resting..." The raccoon replied.

         The leopard nodded, "I see, well let's go have a look then." With that, he and the two mice climbed the stairs to the third floor. The trio of anthros quietly moved down the hallway steadily approaching room 302. Their advance was brought to an abrupt halt when the leopard raised his paw in a closed fist signalling the other two to stop. "Remember," he warned, "We want him to come with us quietly and peacefully. The last thing we want is Terran getting wind of this and scrambling a squad our way. If you you can't talk him down, bring him down as quickly, gently and quietly as possible." Each mouse gave a single nod showing they understood.

         Tom's sleep was interrupted by a firm knock at the door. He growled as he turned over and rolled out of bed, "Housekeeping!" A feminine voice called from the other side if the door.

         Tom froze, "I just got here, there's no freaking way that housekeeping service in a motel is that fast," Tom slung his bag over his shoulder and went out onto the balcony. He gave the rope a test tug before swinginging his leg over the railing and sliding down the rope to the street below.

         Outside of room 302, the mouse that had knocked on the door waited patiently for a reply, but none came. She turned to the leapord who dipped his head in a single nod prompting her to kick the door down. Expecting to find a surprised human, the anthros were shocked to find an empty room. A hole remained in the wall where Tom had cut his way into the other room, the ceiling grate hung open swaying slightly under the breeze of the A/C, and the sliding door to toe balcony sat completely open. "How'd he know we were coming?" The female mouse asked as she surveyed the room.

         "And which way did he go?" The other mouse asked as he shined a flashlight into the open A/C duct.

         "He played us!" The leopard muttered before reaching up and touching a button on his earpiece, "Sierra, he slipped away from us, have you got anything on your end?"

"Sierra here..." came the reply from a cheetah perched atop the opposing building. She too wore the police uniform that her counterparts were in, though she had less equipment as her role was fairly obvious. Her golden eyes keenly focused on Tom, who was on high alert but proceeding at walking pace through the crowds of anthros and the occasional stray or pet human. "I have a visual on the target, should I maintain surveillance?"

         "Understood," The cheetah replied as she stood from her crouching position and stared down at the human who had become her prey. "Alright mister 'Shadow Ghost,' let's see what you've got." The Cheetah bounded down the building landing almost weightlessly on the ground, startling a few bystanders before she darted down the side walk in a light spring, to her at least.

         Tom silently walked down the street. He kept the bill of his cap tilted down to hide his face from oncoming pedestrians. Making eye contact provoked curiosity, and curiosity led to investigation which in turn led to pursuit. Something Tom was less than fond of. Tom glanced behind him to make sure he wasn't being followed. To his surprise, he found a police cheetah closing in on him. "Probably responding to a call..." he thought as he turned and continued walking. After a few seconds he looked again, she was much closer this time, her eyes zeroed in on him. "Or maybe she's coming after me!" Tom muttered as he began sprinting.

         "Stop human!" Sierra called as she continued to close the gap.

         "Oh yeah, no doubt about it," Tom muttered sarcastically to himself, "She's coming for me." Tom ducked into the local mall which happened to be nearby. Several gasps and murmurs greeted him as various anthros stared at him. He didn't stop to entertain them, but moved swiftly to the escalators instead. He froze as he rode it to the top with a string of mall shoppers.

         By the time Tom had reached the halfway point to the second floor, Seirra had burst in to the mall. She glanced ins the ground level, searching for any sign of her target. "Kid gets around pretty quick," She quietly admitted to herself.

Tom kept his eyes on the ground as the escalator drew him closer to the second floor. He knew that if he could blend in with the crowd then he'd be home free. As he reached the top of the escalator Tom glanced back down at the entrance to check on the cheetahs progress. At the moment he turned, so did she. Both of their eyes met. Timed seemed to abruptly slow as they stared at each other, Seirra's eyes widened as realization dawned on her. Tom's pupils shrank as that very same realization flooded his mind and just as abruptly, time began its normal flow again when Seirra dashed toward the base of the escalator and shattered the moment.

         By now Tom had reached the top of the escalator and was making his way to the nearest exit as fast as he could. He glanced over his shoulder to find Seirra leaping over a sheep woman at the top of the escalator and making a beeline straight for him. The human pushed himself to go even faster, but he was already at his limit and it was nowhere near fast enough to keep him ahead of the cheetah. Tom made a sharp right turn and found the doors that led out to the parking garage. He heard the sound of claws scrapin g the tile behind him and knew that his pursuer was close. Tom ran full force into the door with his shoulder, not even bothering to stop and open it. In that very instant he felt an explosion of force hit him from behind. He felt a large hand latch onto his left arm and another arm entirely, wrap itself around his torso. He and Seirra tumbled across the concrete ground in a tangle, the initial advantage Seirra had deteriorated as the rolling and bouncing from the initial collision had broken her hold on the boy. She grasped at him while he struggled to maintain his momentum in an effort to break away in a run.

         Eventually the pair came to a stop in a struggling heap. Seirra had again managed to maintain the high ground as she held Tom face down on the the cold and damp ground with his left arm pinned behind his back and his right arm held firmly in Seirra's paw pointing straight into the air. Tom knew there was only one viable solution to break free and that the odds of it working were almost as ridiculous as actually trying it in the first place.

         Seirra looked up into space for a moment before speaking, "I have the target secured, I had to be a little less than gentle with him.... regrettably... but he seems alright."

"I'll look at that as the glass half full..." Tom muttered as he skidded to a stop and darted down a side street. As he ran through the few pedestrians going about their business, he caught something odd. There were was a bloodhound anthro and a large rat anthro. Both were walking towards a gray van. The odd thing about it was that one of them was carrying a small bear child, and the other was dragging a much older lioness towards the van who was violently struggling to get free.

         The lioness whimpered as she struggled to breathe. Eventually the rat released her before continuing to drag her to the van.

Releasing a long and frustrated sigh Tom looked at the empty street to freedom, "The smart thing to do would be to say 'not my problem' and leave.... 1221111.content:
Kiba was now acutely aware of his situation and he was also aware that it was likely that he was sitting in an interrogation room. The title being pretty self explanatory didn't really leave any room for speculation as to what they were going to do next. However, the question still loomed; what did they want to know?

         Anyone who's ever been interrogated or knows anything about interrogation knows that there are several options for either side to use. There are also several different rules that all depend on who you're dealing with. If you're being interrogated by thugs or criminals, you're only useful as long as you know what they want to know. As long as your useful though, they can't really afford to do away with you, though that won't stop them from trying to beat the answers out of you. It's never any fun to be tortured but the longer you can endure it, the longer you live. If they find out that you don't know anything or that you've given all the information you have, you can expect to find yourself in a shallow grave. The rules are a similar with police, though the stakes aren't as high. Police have rules they have to follow. They can make you uncomfortable, they can threaten you, they can feed you false information to make you second guess yourself... but they can't kill you or beat you with a plank of wood until they break it. If you play you're cards right and feed them bits of useful information for deals or favors that benefit you, you can take a little information and go a long way. Of course if they find out you're lying or you don't have any information to give, you can expect to find yourself in a prison cell pretty quickly.

         Kiba lurched upright in his chair as the door swung open and a bloodhound walked in along with a husky. Both were in police uniforms, the husky was female and the bloodhound was male. The bloodhound dropped a few files on the desk before dropping into his seat while the husky took her seat with much more poise and etiquette.

         "I'll get right to the point," The bloodhound stated, "You are an unregistered human. You look like you're... what? nineteen? Twenty one? Twenty two maybe?" He shrugged. Kiba's expression shifted from neutral to annoyed as he realized that dealing with the bloodhound was going to be less than pleasant. "Honestly who cares? All we know is your older than a ten year old and there's no record of your existence and we want to know why?"

         Kiba sat back in his chair and forced a calm and neutral expression onto his face, "And why should I tell you?"

         "Because," The husky interjected, "Your answer and how cooperative you are will determine what we do with you in regards to your living arrangements."

         "Or," The bloodhound barked, "It could determine how we punish you or execute you... pretty straight forward really."

         Of course, dealing with a police force that has no problem executing you can be a bit of a problem. Especially when the only information you can give is a story that no one will believe. That's when the game changes, it becomes less about the actual interrogation and more about buying time to figure out how to escape.

         "Alright," Kiba replied, "When I was a kid, we were poor. I grew up with my family in a refugee camp. One of your kind would stray in now and again just looking for a place to stay the night. We were fine with that, no harm no foul is what we believed. It wasn't an ideal living condition for anyone but we got by. But one night some thugs came and tore the camp apart and lit it on fire. Burned everything to the ground. I got separated from my family, they didn't make it out in time..." Kiba paused as he sighed. "I'd really rather not tell the rest of this..." The husky looked sympathetic toward you, while the bloodhound only scoffed at your story.

         "Fine," The bloodhound muttered while waving his hands, "Skip ahead a bit."

         Kiba nodded, "Thank you, anyway I basically lived as a thief roaming from small town to small town and stealing what I needed to survive, no more no less. I found a job in a human settlement a few miles from here and I worked there for a while. During one of my shifts working at the warehouse I felt ill and the next thing I knew I woke up in the street here where that wolf officer found me." When Kiba finished his story he knew the odds of them believing it was a longshot. Especially because of the fact that he'd told the wolf he knew nothing of the anthro's hatred toward humans, which was probably common knowledge everywhere in this world as was the reason behind it. Still, if nothing else he'd hoped that their checking into the story would buy him time.... if they bought it that is.

         "That's an interesting story kid..." The bloodhound replied, "Plenty of holes and wiggle room here and there but for the most part that's pretty viable."

         "We'll need a moment to go over what we've heard and check into your story," The husky stated, "We'll be back in a moment." With that the two canine's rose and left the room.

You nodded, "Then before we begin the interrogation, you should know that I fill the role of an interrogator because of some of my unique abilities."

         "What do you mean?" You inquired.

         "Tell me," The wolf prompted, "What do you hear, see and feel?"

         You shrug, "I feel cold and hard handcuffs restraining me to a table. I hear the sound of an very quiet air conditioner and I see a rather intimidating anthro wolf if I'm perfectly honest."

         The wolf nodded, "My senses are significantly heightened when compared to yours. I can see your pupils dilating, I can hear your breathing, I can smell the fear rolling off of your body and I can feel your arms trembling against the table because of the adrenaline running though your veins. If you lie to me, I will sense it through the changes in your body, just think of me as a biological lie detector... but more accurate." You nodded solemnly. "Now, this will be your first, best and only chance that you will have to tell me if the story you've been sticking to thus far is a lie and if your working with anybody who would threaten anyone else's safety."

         "I've been honest with you since I got here," You replied, "I find it hard to believe that I could be suspected of hurting someone like you..." As those words left your mouth, you noticed the wolf's expression change for the briefest of moments from neutral to what you thought was surprise. You have no doubt that if you'd blinked you would've missed it.

         "Very well then, let's begin," The wolf replied. The next few hours consisted of you being interrogated. She asked you questions about your life, questions about what you'd seen since your arrival and sometimes she'd ask you random questions about totally unrelated subjects. She also asked you some of the same questions more than once and every now and again she'd fill in the answer for you with an answer you'd already given her or one that she knew was different from what you'd already told her and then she'd ask you to confirm the answer in both cases. It was obvious that she was using more than just her abilities to determine whether you were lying, she was also trying to see if you'd change any of you're answers. After four hours of questioning the interrogation mercifully came to an end. At length, the wolf sat back in her chair and stared at you with her piercing eyes which seemed to glow even under the bright lights of the room you were in. You stared back at her taking in her expression, searching for even the slightest hint of what she might be thinking, and you were sure that she was doing the same. Time almost seemed to come to a stand still.

         "Alright," The wolf said as she stood up effectively shattering the silence of the moment.

         "Alright what?" You asked in confusion.

         The wolf crossed her arms and stared down at you with a neutral expression, "I believe I've decided on what to do with you."

12211121211.content:
You stood in shock as before you stood what you would have described as three modern day ninja. Each garbed in black robes like the ninja found in folktales and legend wore. However you could clearly see that they had added modern day touches to their attire. Their matte black shoulder pads were a prime example as were the black visors that covered the slit where the older ninja's eyes would have been visible. Their gloves were also reinforced with what looked like hard rubber knuckles and wrist guards. All of these details were of interest to you and brought several questions to your mind, however, there was another detail that stood out above all others, these ninja where human.

         While you were happy to find yourself in the company of your own species you also realized that these three humans have just infiltrated and extracted you from what may have been the most secure facility in the city and you still don't know what their motives are. And given that the police were actually considering protecting you, going along with whatever it is they had in mind gave you pause. For all you know they're mission is your elimination. After all it was common knowledge that many ninja of old killed high profile and high priority targets both for peace and for the right price.

         "What is it that you want from me?" You demanded. However, you were met with silence. "Of course," You sighed, "Ninjas don't talk..."

         At that point, one of the ninjas walked forward and pointed at you before placing an open palm on its chest. You couldn't make out the genders of any of them as their garb did a good job of distorting their actual physical builds. You stared for a moment before you realized what the shinobi was saying. "You want me to come with you?" You asked. All three of the shinobi nodded in response. "Why?" You asked. You question was met by the lead ninja shaking its head. "No?" You asked in confusion, "Do you mean you can't tell me?" You're inquiry was met with a nod this time. Before you could ask any more questions. A loud thud echoed across the rooftop. Several anthros began crawling out of a hatch in the ground, most of them were german shepards, but they were all led by the wolf you'd met previously. The two ninjas behind the leader ran past you and drew short bladed katana and took up a defensive stance between you and the anthros.

         The wolf ordered her officers to hold their positions as she walked forward, "I know you mean us no harm. You're group has always been respectful and tolerant toward our kind and we have granted you quite a bit of leeway for that. However, I cannot allow you to take that human. He may not be of this world and if that is the case, we need to know what we're dealing with." None of the ninja moved except for the one that had begun communicating with you. It walked past you before standing directly in front of you and moving its arm in a horizontal slashing motion.

         The wolf stood up and her face flickered in an almost regretful expression, "Is that your final answer?" She asked. The ninja in front of you nodded, prompting the wolf to sigh, "Then I'm sorry, I didn't want it to come to this but my duties are clear and you leave me no choice. The anthro officers began drawing their guns but before they could even raise them to line up their shots the two shinobi who'd drawn their blades tossed to metallic orbs into the air, each about the size of a baseball. The orbs flashed in a brilliant white and yellow light blinding everyone on the rooftop with the exception of themselves. You felt something hard slam into you stomach while you were blinded by the light and felt yourself beginning to fall to your knees. However, you never hit the ground. From what you could tell, someone was slinging you over their shoulder and carrying you. You presumed it was one of the ninjas. You would have resisted, but those orbs did more than blind you. It seemed that they had impaired your hearing and equilibrium all at once, turning you into a blind drunk capable of rational thought. You don't know what these shinobi had planned for you, but you were going to find out first hand whether you wanted to or not.

122111212111.content:
Eventually your vision starts to clear up and so does your hearing. But you're equilibrium is still shot and the only images you can actually see are after images of what your eyes are able to catch a glimpse of as you're carried along. You buildings, rooftops, police lights and monumental drops to streets that you appear to be hanging over. You also notice that the stead vibration caused by your carrier's running stops all together when you are able to see these drops down to the street. "They must be rooftop jumping" You think as you try to piece together where you are and how far you've traveled, "But to carry me at this pace while jumping rooftops... I know I'm a little on the light side but still... The amount of strength and endurance that would require would be ridiculous."

         You suddenly feel a jolt and all movement stops. You can hear a familiar sound in the background above the hustle and bustle of the city, "I know that noise... What is it?" You think as you hear it again. It suddenly strikes you, "Water! It's water lapping up against a seawall. I can smell the seawater too. We must be at a dock or near a harbor. You then feel yourself being moved by two pairs of hands. The cold hard texture of old wood makes itself present by pressing itself into your backside as you're laid down. "I was right, we are on a dock... You then hear something surface. Whatever it was it did it quietly, because you barely heard a sound. You're vision was still hazy and you were still off keel from the incident on the rooftop. You felt something being placed into your mouth. You resisted at first, but a gloved hand gently but firmly squeezed your cheeks and forced your mouth open. You felt something cold and rubbery fill your mouth making it a little difficult for you to breath. You then felt something cover you're face and the back of your head. After a few more seconds you pieced it together. A regulator had been placed into your mouth and a dive mask around your face. You began breathing through the regulator as the dive mask made it impossible to breathe through your nose. After a few more moments you felt yourself being helped to your feet. By now your vision had completely restored, but your balance was still iffy at best. Your blurry flashes of images became a steady flow of your current surroundings. Two of the shinobi had placed your each of your arms around their necks and were now walking you toward the edge of the dock that you were currently on. What? Are they gonna try to tow me to where we're going... by hand? That's crazy!" You wanted to resist because you honestly thought you were going to drown, however somewhere in your nervous system between your brain and your legs your commands were getting jumbled up because your legs refused to support your weight and moved in a spastic kicking motion while your feet remained limp. After a few more steps the two ninja simply walked off of the dock and dropped into the water with a splash, taking you along for the ride. After submerging themselves you all sank deeper and deeper before coming to a stop at what you'd guess was twenty feet deep. The water was somewhat murky but much cleaner and bluer than you would've expected.

         You continued to simply float in space waiting for whatever it was the shinobi seemed to be waiting for. You thought they were going to swim you somewhere themselves, but all they've done is descended well below visual range from the surface and waited. Suddenly, you saw a glimmer in the distance. You thought is was your imagination, but you had nothing better to do so you did you're best to see if you could find it again, and find it you did. Out of the blue darkness ahead of you swam an anthro shark headed right for you. You couldn't make out to many details between the water and goggles distorting your vision, but from what you could tell, it was female and wearing a scuba suit with black hair... at least that's what you thought you saw. Your initial reaction was to run, but you couldn't. "So this is it..." You thought, "I'm going to be killed by a genetically altered humanoid shark in the waters of an oddly clean harbor... man... that sounded oddly specific and ironic." During all of this, some part of your brain was playing the music from the movie JAWS in your head. "Sure, why not?" You mentally muttered. As you made peace with yourself and prepared to become eradicated from the food chain, you noticed that the shark was slowing and the shinobi were calmly moving towards it. The shinobi pushed you forward as the shark reached for you. Upon her hands (if that's what they were?) making contact with your body, you felt yourself being maneuvered around so that your body was inline with hers. She then held you snugly against her stomach. Out of the corner of your eye you could see each ninja taking up a position near her shoulders before grabbing on to her. Once they had a secure grip she began swimming at a rapid pace back into the darkness from which she came.

         You were tired both physically and mentally. You may not have been doing any of the swimming or running. But your body has had adrenaline pounding through its veins for hours and you haven't had anything to eat in a good while either. Eventually your vision starts to fade to a black. You fight to keep your eyes open, but every time you blink your vision becomes increasingly blurry wand you become more and more drowsy by the second. Your Regulator starts to slip from your mouth when a black gloved hand pushed it back into place and held it there. You find one of the ninja had shifted its position from the shark's shoulder to her underbelly next to you. It was using one arm to cling to the shark's arm while it used the other to hold your regulator in place. After that your consciousness faded from you as the realm of sleep and darkness took over.
